docs.lead_paragraph: SMYTHE--Sheila Mary. The Manhattanville College community mourns the loss of Sheila Mary Smythe, one of its most dedicated and beloved alumni and volunteer leaders, who died on November 4, 2003. Few individuals have so modestly and selflessly served Manhattanville, helping to lead the college through two decades of growth and change while serving as mentor and guide to countless former students of all ages and faiths. Few individuals have so consistently lived the college's mission, to educate ethically and socially responsible leaders for the global community. Miss Smythe, a graduate of Manhattanville College, served on the college's board of trustees for more then 20 years, beginning in 1981. Twice, she oversaw the college's search for a new president, including in 1994, when president Richard A. Berman, who serves today, was chosen. She twice served as chair of the board, most recently serving as vice-chair, member of the executive committee and academic affairs committees and chair of the trustee affairs committee. In 1981, she received the college's Distinguished Alumni Award and in 1974, the college presented her with an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree in recognition of her professional and personal achievements. In 1997, Manhattanville established the Sheila Mary Smythe Award, given periodically to an esteemed alumnus who has successfully worked to improve society. Over her impressive career Miss Smythe was widely respected for her vision and commitment to education and to health care, and for the strong friendships she made throughout her years of business and community leadership. After serving as president and CEO of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, she became the chief health policy advisor to the Comptroller General of the United States (U.S. General Accounting Office). In 1990, she joined New York Medical College as professor of health policy and economics, and the first dean of the Graduate School of Health Sciences. Since 1995, she also served as executive vice president of the college and president of its Partnership for a Healthy Population. In addition to serving Manhattanville College, Miss Smythe served on the boards of many business and community organizations, including the March of Dimes, Catholic Charities USA and Mutual of America Life Insurance Company. Miss Smythe earned Bachelor of Arts degrees from Manhattanville College and Creighton University, and a Master of Science degree from the Graduate School of Public Health and Administrative Medicine at Columbia University, where she also undertook doctoral studies. Miss Smythe is survived by her niece, Sheila P. Gonley, who graduated from Manhattanville College in 1992 and now lives in England. Manhattanville College has established a Shelia Mary Smythe Memorial Fund. Contributions may be sent in Miss Smythe's name to: Manhattanville College, 2900 Purchase Street, Purchase, New York 10504. SMYTHE -- Sheila. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourns the passing of Sheila Smythe, executive vice president of New York Medical College, dean of its School of Public Health, and former president and chief operating officer of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield. During her long, distinguished career, Ms. Smythe was committed to improving the delivery of health care, and was an expert in public health and health care management, finance, policy, and education. We extend our deepest condolences to her friends and loved ones. Stanley Brezenoff, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President GNYHA

docs.lead_paragraph: The ''21'' Club and La Caravelle, two of Manhattan's most venerable restaurants, pride themselves on their sedate atmosphere, but yesterday the scene outside those establishments was anything but sedate as their workers went on strike, and shouted vehemently at anyone heading inside. Nearly 100 cooks, waiters, dishwashers and busboys gathered in front of the ''21'' Club on West 52nd Street in the late morning, forcing the restaurant to close its main dining room for lunch. The strikers bellowed chants that could be heard at the one private function being held there at lunchtime.

headline.main: Workers Go on Strike at 2 of Manhattan's Most Prestigious Restaurants

docs.abstract: Workers go on strike at 21 Club and La Caravelle in Manhattan over restaurants' effort to get them to pay more toward their health insurance; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: They came from Russia, Poland and Lithuania, and their tales of washing and waxing Wal-Mart's floors for seven nights a week sound much like Pavel's. Last February, Pavel responded to an intriguing Web site that boasted of cleaning jobs in the United States paying four times what he was earning as a restaurant manager in the Czech Republic. He flew from Prague to New York on a tourist visa and took a bus to Lynchburg, Va., where a subcontractor delivered him to a giant Wal-Mart.

headline.main: Illegally in U.S., and Never a Day Off at Wal-Mart

docs.abstract: Raids of Wal-Mart stores in 21 states and arrest of 250 janitors expose unseemly secret that hundreds of illegal immigrants work at Wal-Mart stores and subcontractors appear to have violated overtime, Social Security and workers' compensation laws; one Czech worker says he resonded to Web site offering cleaning jobs, flew to New York on tourist visa and took bus to Virginia, where subcontractor delivered him to giant Wal-Mart where he worked every night for next eight months; others also describe experience; photo of Web site; Wal-Mart denies knowing workers were illegal, although federal agents say executives must have known because 102 illegal immigrant janitors were rounded up in 1998 and 2001; officials also say there are recorded conversations with subcontractors (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a case of potentially great significance for managed-care companies and their patients, the Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether health maintenance organizations can be sued for damages for refusing to cover necessary medical treatment. The court granted appeals by two managed-care companies that do business in Texas, where a state law, the Texas Healthcare Liability Act, provides compensatory and punitive damages against H.M.O.'s for coverage decisions that are found to amount to malpractice.

headline.main: Supreme Court Roundup; Court to Review Suits on H.M.O. Policies

docs.abstract: Supreme Court agrees to decide whether health maintenance organizations can be sued for damages for refusing to cover necessary medical treatment; court refuses appeal by Consumers Union of ruling requiring organization to stand trial in 'product disparagement' suit brought by Suzuki Motor Corp stemming from 1988 Consumers Report article on Samurai sport utility vehicle; court refuses to hear appeal by Roy Moore, suspended chief justice of Alabama, of lower federal court orders requiring removal of Ten Commandments monument from state's judicial building; court accepts appeal by Bush administration in case over regulating off-road vehicles in federal wilderness areas in West (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hospitals in New York State are by far the nation's weakest financially -- so weak that nearly half of them have a hard time raising the money needed to invest in renovated wards, new ambulances and improved computer systems, according to a national analysis released last week. Dividing all hospitals into three categories by their ability to raise cash, the report says that in 2001, 43 percent of New York's hospitals fell into the bottom group, with ''limited access to capital,'' compared with 19 percent nationally. The report, by the Healthcare Financial Management Association, a national health industry group, and GE Healthcare Financial Services, with research from PricewaterhouseCoopers, says that the top group, with ''broad access'' to money for capital projects, included 36 percent of hospitals nationwide, but just 8 percent of those in New York. In both groups, New York ranked last among the states.

headline.main: Fiscal Survey Says Hospitals Are Weakest In New York

docs.abstract: Analysis finds that hospitals in New York State and New York City are by far nation's weakest financially--so weak that nearly half of them have hard time raising money needed to invest in renovated wards, new ambulances and improved computer systems; report, dividing all hospitals into three categories by their ability to raise cash, says that in 2001, 43 percent of New York's hospitals fell into bottom group, with 'limited access to capital,' compared with 19 percent nationally; survey findings detailed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Richard H. Carmona, the surgeon general, urged pediatricians on Monday to do more to combat childhood obesity, noting that many overweight children became overweight adults. ''Our children deserve much better than a lifetime of expensive and potentially fatal medical complications associated with excess weight,'' Dr. Carmona said in a speech here to the annual meeting of the American Academy of Pediatrics, which 5,100 physicians and health professionals attend.

headline.main: Pediatricians Urged to Step Up Fight Against Obesity

docs.abstract: Surgeon General Dr Richard H Carmona, addressing annual meeting of American Academy of Pediatrics, urges pediatricians to do more to fight childhood obesity; cites nine million overweight children in US and suggests physicians encourage physical activity and healthy eating; recognizes that medical insurance does not cover time spent with children discussing weight problems, but instead covers medical complications of obesity; internet database to help public awareness of problem is being developed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Workers at a Raytheon Company plant in Tucson, Ariz., that makes Tomahawk cruise missiles voted to accept a revised labor contract, averting a strike that was to begin yesterday. The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers Local 933, which represents about 2,100 of the plant's 10,000 employees, voted 50.3 percent to 49.7 percent to accept the contract, the union said. Union members had voted on Oct. 26 to strike, subject to a seven-day ''cooling off'' period, after rejecting a proposal that would have increased their share of health insurance premiums. Terms of the revised contract were not immediately available. Raytheon is based in Waltham, Mass.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly 100 striking bus drivers agreed on Monday to cut short the strike they had begun just hours earlier in an effort to obtain better health coverage, more paid vacation and something more than the $18 an hour they already get. The drivers, who are responsible for getting 6,200 public and private students to school each day, agreed to return to work immediately, according to Roger Toussaint, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union. But he said they ''reserve the right to renew their strike action at any time'' if they do not see progress at the bargaining table.

headline.main: Greenwich School Bus Drivers' Strike Ends Hours After It Began

docs.abstract: Nearly 100 striking school bus drivers in Greenwich, Conn, agree to cut short strike they had begun just hours earlier in effort to obtain better health coverage, more paid vacation and something more than $18 an hour they already get; drivers, who are responsible for getting 6,200 public and private school students to school each day, agree to return to work immediately (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the season of scratchy throats, stuffy noses and achy muscles arrives, those seeking to protect themselves against flu's miseries have a new option. Instead of an injection, they can receive a painless spritz in each nostril to ward off influenza. The new nasal spray vaccine, FluMist, was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in June for healthy people ages 5 to 49. It was originally developed by Aviron, a California biotechnology company, which MedImmune Inc. of Gaithersburg, Md., bought two years ago.

headline.main: An Option for the Needle-Shy: Spray Flu Vaccine

docs.abstract: FluMist, nasal spray vaccine recently approved by Food and Drug Administration for healthy people ages 5 to 49, will be available for use this flu season; was developed as alternative for those patients who do not like needles; research shows that needle aversion keeps 30 percent of people away from flu shots (M)
